1. Basic Concepts of Logic

Mathematical logic deals with the formal analysis of statements and their connections.

Important Terms:

  • Statement: A sentence that is either true or false
  • Statement Form: A sentence with variables that becomes a statement when values are substituted
  • Quantifiers: $\forall$ for all and $\exists$ there exists

2. Logical Connections

Negation

$$\neg A$$

The negation of a statement $A$ is true if and only if $A$ is false.

Conjunction AND

$$A \land B$$

The conjunction is true if and only if both statements are true.

Disjunction OR

$$A \lor B$$

The disjunction is true if and only if at least one statement is true.

Implication IF-THEN

$$A \Rightarrow B$$

The implication is only false when $A$ is true and $B$ is false.

Equivalence IF AND ONLY IF

$$A \Leftrightarrow B$$

The equivalence is true if and only if both statements have the same truth value.

4. Proof Techniques

Direct Proof

One directly shows that the assertion follows from the premises.

$$\text{Premises} \Rightarrow \text{Assertion}$$

Indirect Proof

One assumes that the assertion is false and leads this to a contradiction.

$$\neg \text{Assertion} \Rightarrow \text{Contradiction}$$

Contraposition

One proves the equivalent statement $\neg B \Rightarrow \neg A$ instead of $A \Rightarrow B$.

$$(A \Rightarrow B) \Leftrightarrow (\neg B \Rightarrow \neg A)$$

5. Examples

Example 1: Direct Proof

Assertion: If $n$ is an even number, then $n^2$ is also even.

$$n = 2k \Rightarrow n^2 = (2k)^2 = 4k^2 = 2(2k^2)$$

Example 2: Indirect Proof

Assertion: $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational.

Assumption: $\sqrt{2}$ is rational $\Rightarrow$ Contradiction to the uniqueness of prime factorization.

Example 3: Contraposition

Assertion: If $n^2$ is odd, then $n$ is odd.

Contraposition: If $n$ is even, then $n^2$ is even.
